questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?(NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger). This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles Involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus,  Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis: These muscles flex the wrist.

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

 

The muscle marked in the image, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension (Incorrect): Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion. It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx. The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension. Muscles Involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus , Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction (Incorrect): Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction. Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself

 

Option D. Abduction (Incorrect): Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction. The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals are essential for the flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, contributing significantly to the dexterity and functional complexity of the hand, particularly in actions that require a combination of flexing and extending different joints of the fingers, such as typing or playing certain musical instruments.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

questions.text: All of the following species of Borrelia are associated with tick-borne relapsing fever, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Borrelia recurrentis

 

Explanation:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is associated with louse-borne relapsing fever (epidemic relapsing fever), not tick-borne relapsing fever. This organism is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) and causes epidemic relapsing fever. The disease manifests as recurring episodes of fever separated by periods of apparent recovery, hence the name "relapsing fever." B. recurrentis is the only species in this group that uses lice as its vector rather than ticks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Borrelia hermsii - This species causes endemic (tick-borne) relapsing fever. It is transmitted by soft ticks and is one of the common causes of tick-borne relapsing fever in North America.

 

Option C. Borrelia turicatae - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever and is transmitted by soft ticks of the genus Ornithodoros. It is endemic in certain regions and belongs to the tick-borne group of relapsing fever Borrelia.

 

Option D. Borrelia duttonii - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever in Africa. It is transmitted by the soft tick Ornithodoros moubata and causes endemic relapsing fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is the only species among those listed that causes louse-borne epidemic relapsing fever, while the other species (B. hermsii, B. turicatae, and B. duttonii) cause tick-borne endemic relapsing fever.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of human immunodeficiency virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Raltegravir


The step 5 in the given image shows the step of integration of the viral genome into the host DNA with the help of Integrase enzyme. Among the above given drugs, Raltegravir can be used to block this step as it is an integrase inhibitor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enfuvirtide: It is fusion inhibitor, which acts by binding to gp41 protein on the surface of the virus. This inhibits the Step 1 of this diagram.

 

Option C. Tenofovir & Option D) Zidovudine: These are NRTIs which are used in combination therapy against HIV virus. NRTI works by inhibiting the activity of reverse transcriptase (Step 6 of the diagram), thereby, preventing the viral replication.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells (Not M cells) present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

M cells, or microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) that play a crucial role in initiating mucosal immune responses, it does not release Motilin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: Addison's disease can present with symptoms similar to which of the following disorders? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones, specifically cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. These symptoms, especially fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss, can overlap with the symptoms of depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder primarily involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday events. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Option C. Bipolar disorder is characterized by mood episodes, including mania (or hypomania) and depression. It may be seen in Addison’s disease, but it is rare.

 

Option D. Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is due to hypofunctioning of the adrenocortical system. It can mimic depression due to overlapping symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low mood. It is essential to consider medical conditions that can present similarly to psychiatric disorders to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 682.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

questions.text: The sensory area marked in the image is primarily innervated by which nerve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

The carotid body chemoreceptors play a crucial role in monitoring and responding to changes in blood oxygen levels, particularly during labor and delivery. These receptors are highly sensitive to decreases in blood oxygen levels (hypoxia) and increases in carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia). When activated, they send signals to the brainstem to increase respiratory rate and heart rate, thereby ensuring adequate oxygen supply to the fetus.

 

During labor, the fetus can experience transient periods of hypoxia due to contractions and reduced placental blood flow. The carotid body chemoreceptors detect these changes and contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration, which is an important indicator of fetal well-being.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Incorrect. Aortic baroreceptors are primarily involved in regulating blood pressure by detecting changes in arterial pressure and activate cardio-vagal (Parasympathetic) center. Their activation leads to reduction in fetal heart rate (not acceleration).

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: Incorrect. While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall cardiovascular regulation, the direct response to hypoxia and resulting heart rate acceleration is mediated by chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): Incorrect. ANP is involved in regulating blood volume and pressure by promoting sodium and water excretion, but it does not directly influence fetal heart rate acceleration during labor.

 

Educational Objective

 

Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: Voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

All the given combinations are correct for the types of transport across a membrane:

 

1. Oxygen. Simple diffusion: Oxygen is a non-polar molecule and diffuses directly across the lipid bilayer of cell membranes by simple diffusion. This process does not require any membrane proteins or energy input.

 

2. Glucose. Facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported into cells via facilitated diffusion, which involves specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT transporters). This process allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient without the use of energy.

 

3. Sodium. Voltage-gated channel: Voltage-gated sodium channels are integral membrane proteins that open and close in response to changes in membrane potential. These channels allow the selective passage of sodium ions during the action potentials in neurons and muscle cells.

 

4. Sodium. Secondary active transport: Sodium ions are also involved in secondary active transport, where the movement of sodium down its electrochemical gradient (established by primary active transport) drives the transport of another substance against its gradient. An example is the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT).

 

5. Calcium. Active transport: Calcium ions are actively transported across cell membranes using ATP-driven pumps such as the Ca²⁺-ATPase (also known as the calcium pump). This process maintains low intracellular calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the mentioned substances and their associated transport mechanisms are correct: Oxygen via simple diffusion, glucose via facilitated diffusion, sodium via voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport, and calcium via active transport.

choices.text: A, B, C, D
A, C, D

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. ECHO.
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan.
  3. Thermodilution.
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography is a method for detecting the direction and velocity of moving blood within the heart. This is also a popular method to measure cardiac output.

 

Option C. Thermodilution method - a known volume of cold sterile solution is injected into the right atrium via inferior vena cava by using a catheter. Cardiac output is measured by determining the resultant change in the blood temperature in pulmonary artery. For this purpose, two thermistors (temperature transducers) are used. One of them is placed in the inferior vena cava and the second one is placed in pulmonary artery. A pulmonary artery catheter is used to place the thermistors in their positions.

 

Option D. The Fick principle, as applied to cardiac output, relies on the recognition that the total uptake of oxygen by the peripheral tissues is equal to the product of the blood flow to the peripheral tissues and the arterial-venous oxygen concentration difference.

Formula:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:

 

  1. By using Fick principle
  2. Indicator (dye) dilution technique
  3. Thermodilution technique
  4. Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique
  5. Doppler echocardiography
  6. Ballisto cardiography.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

 

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

 

Median Nerve supplies the following intrinsic muscle of hand-

 

  • Thenar Muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis. (Note: The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve.)
  • Lumbricals: The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals, which flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the index and middle fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN): 

  • This nerve doesn't directly supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. It's mainly responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the forearm.

 

Option C. Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN): 

  • The AIN is a branch of the median nerve but doesn't directly supply the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Instead, it supplies deep muscles in the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus and the radial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: This nerve supply the following intrinsic muscle of hand

 

  • Hypothenar Muscles: Abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, and opponens digiti minimi.
  • Interossei: Both the dorsal and palmar interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve. They are responsible for abduction and adduction of the fingers, respectively.
  • Third and Fourth Lumbricals: These lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the ring and little fingers.
  • Adductor Pollicis: This muscle, as mentioned before, is involved in thumb adduction and is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • Other Hand Muscles: Deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis and all the palmaris brevis muscles are also supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

 

 

MCP = Metacarpophalangeal; IP = Interphalangeal; FDP = Flexor Digitorum Profundus.

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.
