questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ritonavir


 

  • Both Ritonavir and Saquinavir are Protease inhibitors that can be used in the treatment of HIV.
  • They are metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme system. But at the same time, Ritonavir is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4. Therefore, if small doses of Ritonavir are added along with Saquinavir, it will inhibit the metabolism of Saquinavir or in other words will boost the bioavailability and concentration of Saquinavir.

choices.text: Treatment of migraine
Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
Prophylaxis of ADHD
Treatment of dementia

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

 

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that can be used for the treatment of Lennaux-Gestaut Syndrome (characterized by multifocal seizures, having <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG). It primarily works by blocking the Na+ channels, and to some extent it also enhances the GABA receptor currents and limiting the activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.

 

Topiramate can also be used for:

 

  • C: Decreasing the Craving of alcohol
  • O: Obesity
  • M: Migraine Prophylaxis (not treatment)
  • B: Bipolar disorder.

 

So, among the given options, best answer is Lennox Gastaut syndrome. Do not get confused with migraine as the options specifically mentions the treatment of migraine whereas topiramate is used for prophylaxis of migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of migraine: Topiramate is used for the prophylaxis of migraines, not for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.

 

Option C. Prophylaxis of ADHD: Topiramate is not indicated for the prophylaxis or treatment of ADHD.

 

Option D. Treatment of dementia: Topiramate is not used for the treatment of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: New drug application is filed after phase 4
Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance
Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding
Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding clinical trials? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance

 

Phase 4 clinical trials are also called post-marketing surveillance. This statement is correct. Phase 4 trials are conducted after a drug has been approved and marketed to monitor its long-term effectiveness and safety.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. New drug application is filed after phase 4: This statement is incorrect. The New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, not Phase 4. Phase 4 occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed.

 

Option C. Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding: This statement is incorrect. Phase 3 clinical trials are typically randomized and double-blinded to eliminate bias and ensure robust results. Open label studies, where both the participants and investigators know which treatment is being administered, are less common in Phase 3 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals: This statement is incorrect. Phase 2 clinical trials are conducted on patients who have the condition that the drug is intended to treat. Phase 1 trials, on the other hand, are usually done on healthy volunteers to assess safety and dosage.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Article 21 

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the Right to Life and personal liberty to all its citizens. This article is pivotal as it ensures that no person is deprived of their life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law. This right is comprehensive, covering a range of aspects that ensure not just mere survival but a life with dignity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Article 11: Defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

 

Option C. Article 23: Defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

 

Option D. Article 25: Defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion. While it pertains to personal liberties, it specifically addresses religious freedoms and not the general Right to Life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is critical as it enshrines the Right to Life and personal liberty, ensuring that every individual's life and personal freedoms are protected under the law.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is the most resistant to antiseptics? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Prions

 

Explanation:

 

Prions are the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfectants. Prions require specific and extreme sterilization methods compared to other microorganisms. The recommended methods for prion sterilization are particularly aggressive: autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours, treatment with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour, or using 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spores - While bacterial spores are highly resistant to many antiseptics, they are less resistant than prions. Spores can be killed by proper autoclaving (121°C for 15 minutes) or using strong disinfectants like glutaraldehyde (2% for 10-14 hours).

 

Option C. Cysts - Cysts of protozoa are moderately resistant to antiseptics but less resistant than both spores and prions. They don't require the extreme conditions needed for prion inactivation.

 

Option D. Fungi - Fungi are generally susceptible to intermediate-level disinfectants. Intermediate-level disinfectants including alcohols, phenolics, and halogens are effective against fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions require the most extreme sterilization conditions of all infectious agents, including extended high-temperature autoclaving (134°C for 1-1.5 hours) or strong chemical treatment (1N NaOH or concentrated hypochlorite), making them the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfection methods.

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the most appropriate method for the provisional diagnosis of Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from pustular lesions. Group A streptococci characteristically show susceptibility to bacitracin, which serves as a key diagnostic feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. The test is performed by placing a bacitracin disk on a culture plate and observing for a zone of inhibition around the disk, which indicates susceptibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test helps differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). Finding catalase positivity would actually point away from streptococcal infection and toward staphylococcal infection.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is specifically used for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci), not Group A streptococci. S. pneumoniae is highly sensitive to optochin, while other streptococci including Group A are typically resistant.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is used primarily for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile whereas other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not bile soluble. This test would not help confirm a Group A streptococcal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the key diagnostic test for the provisional identification of Group A Streptococcus from clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin being a distinctive characteristic that helps differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

choices.text: Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban
Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban
Idarucizumab: Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match regarding FDA approved antidotes of anticoagulants? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

 

FDA-approved antidotes for specific anticoagulants are designed to counteract the effects of these drugs in cases of excessive bleeding or when rapid reversal is required for surgery or other urgent medical situations.

 

Ciraparantag is a broad-spectrum antidote that has shown effectiveness against various anticoagulants, including dabigatran, oral factor Xa inhibitors, low molecular weight heparins (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH), and fondaparinux. However, it is important to note that Ciraparantag is not currently FDA-approved for these indications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban: Andexanet alfa is an FDA-approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors, including Edoxaban, Apixaban, and Rivaroxaban. It works by binding to and sequestering the factor Xa inhibitors, thus reversing their anticoagulant effects.

 

Option B. Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban: Similarly, Andexanet alfa is also the antidote for Rivaroxaban, a factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Option C. Idarucizumab: Dabigatran: Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to Dabigatran, an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, and neutralizes its anticoagulant effect. This antidote is FDA-approved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Andexanet alfa is the approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors like Edoxaban and Rivaroxaban, while Idarucizumab is the antidote for Dabigatran. Although Ciraparantag has shown promise as a broad-spectrum antidote, it is not FDA-approved for use with fondaparinux or other anticoagulants.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as - 1/contraction period.

 

In this problem, contraction period is 40msec = 0.04sec

 

So, Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanization-  As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and increase exercise capacity of a person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pirfenidone

 

Pirfenidone is a synthetic pyridine drug that acts as an antifibrotic agent with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. It is used to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Pirfenidone helps to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and improves exercise capacity in patients with IPF. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of fibroblasts and reducing the production of pro-fibrotic cytokines, thereby slowing down the fibrotic process in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roflumilast: Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitor indicated for the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It reduces inflammation and improves lung function in patients with COPD but is not used for treating pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Option C. Imatinib: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). It works by inhibiting the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, but it does not have a role in the treatment of pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Option D. Bortezomib: Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. It inhibits the proteasome pathway, leading to cancer cell death. It is not used for treating pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pirfenidone is the drug used to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and increase exercise capacity in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). It has antifibrotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties that help to manage this condition. Other drugs like roflumilast, imatinib, and bortezomib are used for different medical conditions and do not have the same therapeutic effects on pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LH

 

The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein having a molecular weight of about 39,000 and much the same molecular structure and function as luteinizing hormone secreted by the pituitary gland. Its most important function is to prevent involution of the corpus luteum at the end of the monthly female sexual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect. Although FSH is also a glycoprotein hormone, it has a different function and structure compared to hCG.

 

Option C. ACTH: Incorrect. ACTH is a peptide hormone involved in the stress response, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Incorrect. Oxytocin is a peptide hormone involved in labor and milk ejection, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to Luteinizing Hormone (LH). Its primary role is to support the corpus luteum during early pregnancy, preventing its involution.

questions.text: In the image provided, which muscle is most likely represented by the blue-colored area? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the base of the second metacarpal bone on the dorsal side.
  • Action: This muscle extends and abducts the wrist. It helps in the extension of the wrist joint and also assists in radial abduction.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the radial nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brachioradialis:

 

  • Origin: This muscle originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the lateral surface of the radius near its styloid process.
  • Action: The primary function is to flex the elbow. However, unlike most other flexors of the elbow, which are pronators, the brachioradialis is a supinator when the forearm is pronated and a pronator when the forearm is supinated, making it a neutralizer of the forearm.
  • Innervation: The brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Supinator:

 

  • Origin: The supinator muscle has a two-headed origin – one from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (by the radial collateral ligament) and one from the proximal ulna (from the annular ligament and the supinator crest).
  • Insertion: It wraps around the upper third of the radius.
  • Action: As its name suggests, it supinates the forearm, meaning it rotates the forearm to turn the palm anteriorly or upwards.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis brevis:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.
  • Action: This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the site X shown in the figure? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrochlorothiazide

 

The site X in the given image represent distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is a thiazide diuretic that acts by blocking the Na-Cl symporter in the DCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle (marked B) and inhibits the Na-K-2Cl symporter.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Is an Aldosterone receptor blocker acting on the collecting ducts (marked Y).

 

Option D. Acetazolamide. Is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubules (marked A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and promoting diuresis. This makes it effective for treating conditions such as hypertension and edema. Other diuretics like furosemide, spironolactone, and acetazolamide act on different parts of the nephron and have distinct mechanisms of action.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

questions.text: What importance does the point labelled as 'C' hold? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Onset of symptoms

 

  • The given image depicts timeline of natural history of disease in an individual over time, in which the point labelled C denotes the onset of symptoms.

 

 

 

  • Natural history of disease describes the natural course of the disease from its early pre pathogenesis phases to termination.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The onset of symptoms marks the transition from the subclinical stage to the clinical stage of disease.

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 96% 

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that to achieve the complete elimination of measles, an immunization coverage of at least 96% among children under the age of 1 is necessary. 
  • This high percentage is critical because measles is highly contagious. Such a high coverage rate ensures herd immunity, significantly reducing the chances of measles transmission and protecting those who are not immune.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: During a histological examination of the oral cavity, which combination of features is typically seen in the hard palate mucosa? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa. It is composed of keratinized epithelium, a submucosal layer for support, and contains minor salivary glands. These structures contribute to the function of the hard palate in speech, mastication (chewing), and the initial digestion of food in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

choices.text: 1 month
3 months
No need to stop
Can be stopped and conceived soon after stopping

questions.text: A lady who had undergone mastectomy for breast cancer is being treated with tamoxifen. How long should it be stopped for before she can conceive?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 months

 

  • Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), which is used in Premenopausal women having ER +ve breast cancer, because of its anti-estrogenic action in the breast. It prevents the chance of recurrence of breast cancer after surgery.
  • The half-life of tamoxifen is approximately 5 to 7 days, but its active metabolites can persist in the body for several weeks. To minimize any risk to a potential pregnancy, it is recommended to stop tamoxifen at least 3 months before trying to conceive.
  • Tamoxifen has teratogenic effects, such as craniofacial abnormalities and reproductive tract abnormalities. It is also stopped during lactation as it is secreted in breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen should be stopped for at least 3 months before attempting to conceive due to its long half-life and potential teratogenic effects. This ensures that the drug and its active metabolites are sufficiently cleared from the body, reducing the risk of harm to the fetus.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convergence

 

Convergence refers to the process by which multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, resulting in the integration of information from different sources. In this scenario, the single neuron is receiving inputs from 150 sensory neurons, indicating that there is convergence of input onto the single neuron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Divergence: Divergence occurs when a single neuron sends its axon to synapse with multiple downstream neurons. This process spreads information from one neuron to many.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: This is a regulatory mechanism where a neuron sends a signal to inhibit its own activity indirectly through a network of intermediate neurons. It’s not relevant to the scenario described.

 

Option D. Feedforward excitation: This mechanism involves a neuron sending excitatory signals to downstream neurons to propagate an action potential. It’s not directly related to the scenario described.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

choices.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.text: The table below gives the AUC of drug B alone and that of drug B when combined with another drug A. If the p value is <0.01, then which of the following statements is true? (INICET 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
 

  • The area under the curve or AUC in plasma concentration vs time graph can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug. The bioavailability of a given drug refers to the fraction of the given dose which reaches the systemic circulation. The greater the area under the curve or AUC, the greater is the bioavailability.
  • From the given data, it is seen that the AUC for Drug B is less than the AUC for Drug A + Drug B. And the p value <0.01 indicates that the data is statistically significant. (As the p value is <0.05)
  • So, it can be inferred that the Drug A increases the bioavailability of drug B.

 

As bioavailability depends on two factors:

 

  • Absorption (Bioavailability is directly proportional to the rate of drug absorption)
  • First Pass Metabolism (Bioavailability is inversely proportional to the rate of first pass metabolism of the drug)
  • Therefore, it can be assumed that drug B either increase the absorption or decrease the first pass metabolism of drug A.
  • So among the given options, best answer seem to be option B: Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of drug B

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A decreased the intestinal absorption of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined, not higher.

 

Option C. Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the metabolism of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined.

 

Option D. Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the renal elimination of Drug B, it would lead to a decrease in AUC, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in the AUC of Drug B when combined with Drug A, with a statistically significant p value, indicates that Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of Drug B, thereby increasing its bioavailability.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is most likely affected here ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

 

  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to weakness or atrophy of the lumbrical and interossei muscles in the hand.
  • These muscles play a crucial role in flexing the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints through their attachment to the dorsal digital expansions.
  • As a result of the nerve injury, the MCP joints may become extended, while the IP joints may become flexed.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor digitorum: This muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the dorsal digital expansions of the medial four fingers.

 

  • It acts primarily to extend the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints of the fingers.
  • If the extensor digitorum were affected, you would expect difficulty in extending the MCP and IP joints.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis: 

  • It refers to two muscles, the abductor pollicis longus (located in the forearm) and abductor pollicis brevis (intrinsic hand muscle) whose primary function is to abduct the thumb. Dysfunction would primarily impact thumb movements and would not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: 

  • It is one of the thenar muscles of the hand and plays a key role in thumb movement, especially in its abduction. Like the abductor pollicis longus, an issue with this muscle would impact thumb movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).

choices.text: Hydralazine - heart failure
Atenolol - hemolytic anemia
Aliskiren - hypokalemia

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation


The correct match regarding the drug and its adverse effect (read carefully, they have not asked the indication) is verapamil causes constipation.

 

Verapamil is a Non DHP calcium channel blocker. It can cause constipation as its side effect.


Other Options:


Option A. Hydralazine is a vasodilator which can cause drug-induced lupus. It does not cause heart failure as an adverse effect, rather It is used in treatment of heart failure.


Option B. Atenolol is a cardio selective beta blocker. Bradycardia can be seen as a side effect, not hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is a side effect of methyl dopa.


Option C. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. The side effect of aliskiren is hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

questions.text: Seman's squeeze technique is used for which of the following conditions?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature ejaculation

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a behavioral therapy method used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the man or his partner squeezing the tip of the penis for several seconds right before ejaculation is expected. This helps in delaying ejaculation. The other options do not involve the use of this technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation refers to the backward flow of semen into the bladder instead of out of the penis.

 

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection suitable for intercourse. 

 

Most successful psychotherapy for erectile dysfunction is dual-sex therapy by Masters and Johnson.

 

Option D. Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation is pain felt during or after ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as stop-start technique. Another non-pharmacological treatment includes squeeze technique, where the female partner squeezes the coronal ridge of the glans, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Live and subcutaneous: While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C. Live and intramuscular: Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D. Killed and subcutaneous: Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT

 

Macula densa are specialized cells in the end portion of thick ascending segment before it opens into distal convoluted tubule. It is situated between afferent and efferent arterioles of the same nephron. It is very close to afferent arteriole. Macula densa is formed by tightly packed cuboidal epithelial cells. It forms the part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of thick descending limb and DCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not located at the junction of the thick descending limb and the distal convoluted tubule.

 

Option B. Junction of thick descending limb and PCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not found at the junction of the thick descending limb and the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Option D. Junction of DCT and collecting duct: Incorrect. The macula densa is located before the DCT opens into the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa is composed of specialized cells located at the junction of the thick ascending limb and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), playing a crucial role in the juxtaglomerular apparatus.
